summary: An FBI email from July 15, 2019, detailing the discovery of multiple passports belonging to Jeffrey Epstein during a search of suitcases, including a fraudulent Austrian passport under the alias 'Marius Robert Fortelni'. The email also mentions a US Treasury Customs Service badge found among his possessions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the document; multiple US passports and a fraudulent Austrian passport were found in his suitcases.

persons.name: Marius Robert Fortelni
persons.context: The name listed on a fraudulent Republic of Austria passport found in Epstein's possession, with a listed residence in Saudi Arabia and a date of birth of July 30, 1954.

connections.description: Epstein possessed a fraudulent Austrian passport issued under the alias 'Marius Robert Fortelni'.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's passports and badge
events.description: FBI personnel reviewed suitcases and discovered five U.S. passports and one fraudulent Republic of Austria passport for Jeffrey Epstein, along with a US Treasury Customs Service badge.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein possessed at least five U.S. passports with various expiration dates from the 1970s to 2005.

Epstein possessed a fraudulent Republic of Austria passport under the alias 'Marius Robert Fortelni', listing a date of birth of July 30, 1954, and a residence in Dammam, Saudi Arabia. The passport expired on May 21, 1987.

A US Department of Treasury Customs Service badge or lapel pin was found among Epstein's possessions, described as possibly a novelty item as it was in an oversized credential wallet with no accompanying credentials.
The document is an internal FBI email from the New York C-20 Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking Task Force, indicating an active investigation into Epstein in July 2019.
